children.text: Loops repeat sections of code. Using loops can also be called ‘iteration’ or 'repetition.'
to scroll ‘micro:bit’ on the LED display 3 times.
line is not indented, so it’s not in the loop and it only runs once.
The micro:bit Python editor will add indentations for you when it thinks you need one, for example when you press ‘enter’ after typing

Indentations are usually 4 spaces or one tab character. You must be consistent, you can’t use 4 spaces on one line and 3 on another. The code highlighting in the editor helps you check that your indentations line up correctly.
You can indent any lines you have highlighted by pressing the tab key on your keyboard. You can remove indentations by pressing shift+tab.
Python uses indentations to show which instructions are inside and outside a loop.

content.main:
from microbit import *


for i in range(3):  
    display.scroll('micro:bit')
display.scroll('Python')

children.text: Infinite, or 'forever', loops keep a program running.
In the example above, the word ‘micro:bit’ will scroll across the LED display forever.
is a common way to continuously check inputs like sensor readings or if a button has been pressed:
keep a block of code running as long as something is true.

content.main:
from microbit import *


number = 0
while number < 10:
    display.scroll(number)
    number = number + 1
display.scroll('finish')

has a value less than 10. When the value reaches 10, the loop ends, so it will count from 0 to 9.

Python uses indentations to tell the computer exactly what instructions should be carried out in each case, similar to the way it uses indentations to show which lines of code are in a
You can compare numbers to make different things happen if they are equal, smaller, larger or not equal to something.

from microbit import *

    display.scroll('Number is less than 5')

from microbit import *

if number > 5:
    display.scroll('Number is greater than 5')

from microbit import *


number = 5
if number <= 5:
    display.scroll('Number is less than or equal to 5')

from microbit import *


number = 5
if number >= 5:
    display.scroll('Number is greater than or equal to 5')

from microbit import *


number = 23
if number != 5:
    display.scroll('Number is not equal to 5')

Triggered when you shake your micro:bit:
Triggered when the micro:bit is upright with the logo at the top:
Triggered when the micro:bit is upside down with the logo at the bottom:
Triggered when the micro:bit is lying flat with the LED display facing up:
Triggered when your micro:bit is lying flat with its LED display facing down:
Triggered when the micro:bit is tilted left or held upright with the logo on the left:
Triggered when the micro:bit is tilted right or held upright with the logo on the right:
Triggered when the accelerometer detects it's falling towards the ground:

1g is the equivalent to the pull of gravity. 3g and above are the kinds of acceleration experienced by racing car drivers or astronauts leaving Earth. It’s hard to generate accelerations above 3g in a classroom.
to test if a gesture has occurred at any point since the last time you tested it.

The micro:bit measures acceleration in milli-g units, one thousandths of the Earth’s gravity.
When the micro:bit is lying flat on a table, you should see that the x and y readings are close to 0, but the z reading will be about -1000. This is because the accelerometer is measuring gravity.
The minimum and maximum readings you can get from the accelerometer are about -2000 or +2000 milli-g.
The accelerometer can read the strength of acceleration in 3 dimensions: x, y and z.

children.text: to learn more about using lists in Python.
Mathematical operations are not calculated in order from left to right. Some operations take precedence over others. In Python, operations are carried out in this order:
You may know precedence as BODMAS or BIDMAS (brackets, orders or indices, division, multiplication, addition, subtraction).

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *

display.scroll(2 + 3 * 4)
display.scroll((2 + 3) * 4)

children.text: In this example, the first number shown is 14 because the multiplication happens before the addition: 3 is multiplied by 4 to make 12 and then 2 is added.
The second number shown is 20. The brackets around
mean that the addition is done first. 2 + 3 = 5, which is then multiplied by 4 to make 20.

contents.name: Functions
contents.subtitle: Make your code more efficient

children.text: Python has many built-in functions like
, but you can make your own to re-use sections of code in your programs.
Functions make code easier to read and modify. Define your function near the start of your program, giving it a descriptive name, then call it using its name followed by round brackets.
Procedures, also called sub-routines, are functions that carry out a fixed set of instructions.

content.main:
from microbit import *

def heart_wait():
    display.show(Image.HEART)
    sleep(1000)

heart_wait()
display.clear()

children.text: shows a heart on the micro:bit's LED display, then waits 1 second.
You can put data in brackets to pass to a function, which the function can then process.

content.main:
from microbit import *

def image_wait(myImage):
    display.show(myImage)
    sleep(1000)

image_wait(Image.HEART)
image_wait(Image.HEART_SMALL)

children.text: In this example, we define a function called
. This will show any image we pass to the function.
Data you pass to a function are called parameters. Parameters make functions more flexible.

You can send more than one parameter to a function. This function allows you to specify both the image and how long the function waits. The default delay is 1 second, but you can over-ride it by specifying a new time when you call the function:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *

def image_wait(myImage, delay=1000):
    display.show(myImage)
    sleep(delay)

image_wait(Image.HEART)
image_wait(Image.HEART_SMALL, delay=3000)
display.clear()

content.main:
from microbit import *


def convertCtoF(c):
    return c * 1.8 + 32

display.scroll(convertCtoF(temperature()))

children.text: This function takes any number you pass to it, modifies it using the formula to convert centigrade to Fahrenheit, and returns it.
statement. The current temperature in centigrade is passed to the function.
‘Function' is a mathematical term describing a relation or expression involving one or more variables, such as F = C x 1.8 + 32.
Functions in computer programs work in a similar way, which is why they are good for performing calculations and conversions.
Variables aren’t always available to all parts of your program. Sometimes this is what you want, but it can cause problems. Variables can be
Global variables can be accessed by any part of your program. Local variables only work inside a section of your program such as a function.
If you create a variable outside a function definition, it will be global and can be used by the function.

content.main:
from microbit import *


def greeting():
    display.scroll('Hello ' + name)

name = 'Sam'
greeting()

children.text: In this example the display shows ‘Hello Sam’.

is called, or you will get an error.
If you want to modify the value of a
variable in a function, you must declare that you want to use the global variable of that name using
Here we use the global variable count to track how many times the function has been called:
Variables inside functions are assumed to be

content.main:
from microbit import *


def count():
    number = 9
    display.show(number)

number = 5
count()
sleep(1000)
display.show(number)

children.text: Here we have two instances of a variable called
is a local variable with a value of 9.
Outside the function there is a
You might expect that calling the function would change the value of
to 9 and show 9 twice. But in fact this will show 9 and then 5 on the display because we have two different variables both called
. One is local to the function and has the value 9, the other is global and has the value 5.

contents.subtitle: Send messages between micro:bits

children.text: You can send messages between micro:bits by radio. You need to import the radio module near the start of your program using
First set a radio group so you know your message is going to the right micro:bit or set of micro:bits:
Groups work like radio channels. Any micro:bits using the same group number can share radio messages.
You can use any group number between 0 and 255.
Because the radio feature uses more power, you might want to turn it off at certain times to save batteries:

detailContent.main:
import radio


radio.off()

children.text: You need to turn the radio on before you use it:
You can send strings over radio made up of letters, symbols and numbers:
Because you don’t know when a radio message might be sent, it’s a good idea to keep checking for new messages in a loop. This will show new messages when they arrive:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import radio


radio.on()
while True:
    message = radio.receive()
    if message:
        display.scroll(message)

children.text: 0 is the lowest power setting, 7 is the highest. Radio signals travel further with higher power, but use more energy.
You may want to reduce the power to make your batteries last longer, or in a radio treasure hunt game so that you have to get physically close to a micro:bit to pick up its signal.
You can optionally set the radio transmit power in a range from 0 to 7:

contents.subtitle: Measure light falling on your micro:bit

children.text: The LEDs on the micro:bit can also act as a light sensor:
The strength of light falling on the micro:bit is measured as a number from 0 - 255, with 0 being the darkest and 255 the brightest.
This lights up the LED display with a heart when the light level falls below 50:

contents.subtitle: Measure your micro:bit’s temperature

children.text: Because the processor makes a small amount of heat, readings are normally a bit higher than the temperature in the air around the micro:bit, so you may want to compare readings with a real thermometer and adjust them.
The micro:bit has a temperature sensor inside its processor. You can take temperature readings in centigrade like this:

contents.name: Temperature

contents.subtitle: Measure direction and strength of magnetic fields

children.text: The micro:bit has a compass sensor that can measure its heading or bearing from magnetic North in degrees:

content.alt: Diagram of a compass rose and micro:bit showing that bearings are measured from the top of the micro:bit clockwise when held flat

children.text: The first time you use the compass you may be asked to calibrate it by playing a little game. ‘TILT TO FILL SCREEN’ scrolls across the display. Tilt the micro:bit until every LED light is lit, and then a happy face appears. This ensures the compass gives accurate readings. You can also make your program calibrate the compass every time it runs:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *


compass.calibrate()

children.text: You can use the compass as a magnetometer, to measure the strength of magnetic fields. It can do this in 3 dimensions, and also measure overall strength of magnetic fields in all dimensions at once.

content.alt: micro:bit showing X axis going across the front, Y axis going down and up, Z axis going back to front

content.main:
from microbit import *

magnet_strength_x = compass.get_x()
display.scroll(magnet_strength_x)

from microbit import *

magnet_strength_y = compass.get_y()
display.scroll(magnet_strength_y)

from microbit import *

magnet_strength_z = compass.get_z()
display.scroll(magnet_strength_z)

from microbit import *

magnet_strength_all = compass.get_field_strength()
display.scroll(magnet_strength_all)

children.text: The compass measures magnetic field strength in units called nanoteslas (nT). Readings can be positive or negative, depending on the direction of the magnetic field.

contents.subtitle: Play music, speech and other sounds

children.text: The micro:bit can play tunes and even speak. The V2 micro:bit has a built-in speaker, and you can attach headphones or an amplified speaker to any micro:bit’s 0 and GND
near the start of your program to use the music features.
The micro:bit will wait until the tune has finished playing before carrying out the next instruction in your code. If you want something to happen while the music is still playing, add

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import music


music.play(music.PYTHON, wait=False)
display.show(Image.SNAKE)

children.text: You can set the tempo, or speed, of music played by the micro:bit:
Tempo is measured in bpm, beats per minute. Numbers lower than 120 are slower than normal, higher than 120 are faster.
You can use musical notation to play tunes:
By default it plays notes in the 4th octave. You can specify other octaves.
This example plays the notes C, D, E, C in the 3rd octave:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import music
 
music.play(['c3', 'd3', 'e3', 'c3'])

children.text: You can choose how long each note plays using a colon and number after the note name. Here the note G4 plays for twice as long as the other notes:

detailContent.main:
import music


music.play(['e4:4', 'f4:4', 'g4:8'])

children.text: Rests can be added using the note name 'r' for any duration you specify.
You can use flat notes by adding ‘b’ to the note name and sharp notes with ‘#’. This plays A flat, A natural and A sharp:

detailContent.main:
import music


music.play(['ab', 'a', 'a#'])

children.text: The micro:bit can play sounds defined by frequency or pitch:
This will play a note at 440Hz (the note A).
The sound will continue playing until you change or stop it:

detailContent.main:
import music


music.stop()

children.text: This example produces a sound like a siren rising from 100 Hz to 1000 Hz:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import music


for p in range(100,1000):
    music.pitch(p)
    sleep(5)
music.stop()

children.text: You can make your micro:bit speak using Python:

content.main:
import speech


speech.say('Hello, world. How are you?')

children.text: ), a longer pause with a comma (
) and change the inflection using full stops (
to discover more about how to use speech, create different voices and even make your micro:bit sing.
The micro:bit V2 with built-in speaker can also make some expressive sounds to add personality to your projects.
You can adjust the volume of the micro:bit V2’s audio output using numbers in the range 0 to 255:
Adjusting the volume affects both the speaker and audio output from the pins. This feature only works on the micro:bit V2.
Mute the V2 micro:bit’s built-in speaker, but still have sound available on the pins for headphones:

You can set the threshold for loud or quiet events using numbers in the range 0-255.

microphone.set_threshold(SoundEvent.LOUD, 200)
microphone.set_threshold(SoundEvent.QUIET, 1)

children.text: The micro:bit V2 has a built-in microphone. It's situated on the back of the micro:bit, and there’s a hole on the front to the right of the touch logo to let the sound in. There’s also a microphone LED on the front that lights up when the microphone is in use.

contents.subtitle: Use the gold logo as an extra button

children.text: The micro:bit V2 has a gold logo on the front that you can use as an extra button when you touch it:
By default the touch logo on the micro:bit V2 uses
touch. This means that, unlike the default
touch behaviour of the pins, you can just touch the button with your finger, you don’t also need to hold the GND pin.
in the API documentation for more information.

contents.subtitle: Log sensor data on your micro:bit

children.text: The micro:bit V2 can log sensor data to a file on the micro:bit. After logging your data, plug the micro:bit into a computer and open
on the MICROBIT drive to view your data in a web browser, or download it as a CSV file for use in a spreadsheet.
This example will create three column headings titled
The first column in your log holds the timestamp and will be added to every row of data. You can set the format of the timestamp when you set your column labels to
if you want to disable the timestamp.
This example sets the format to record the time in  'hours':

detailContent.main:
import log 

log.set_labels('temperature', 'sound', 'light', timestamp=log.HOURS)

children.text: To set up data logging, you need to provide descriptions for your data. These will appear as the column headings:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import log


log.set_labels('temperature', 'sound', 'light')

children.text: You can log data from any of the built-in sensors on your micro:bit:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import log


log.add({
  'temperature': temperature(),
  'sound': microphone.sound_level(),
  'light': display.read_light_level()
})

children.text: The example above adds an entry to the
The headings and values are passed to
is a data structure that consists of key:value pairs inside curly brackets
. Each entry contains the label and the value associated with it.
Instead of using dictionary values, you can alternatively use
. This example logs the same data:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import log


log.add(
    temperature=temperature(),
    sound=microphone.sound_level(),
    light=display.read_light_level()
)

children.text: You can use a scheduler to log data automatically at regular intervals:
This example logs data every 30 seconds.
You can use multiple time unit parameters, so for example you could use
to log data every 1 hour 20 minutes 30 seconds and 50 ms.

contents.subtitle: Expand your micro:bit

children.text: The micro:bit has gold pins on its lower edge you can use to connect input and output devices like headphones, LEDs, switches, motors, sensors and other electronic components.
Pins 0, 1 and 2 are GPIO pins: general purpose input/output. There are
that you can access with an edge-connector or breakout board.

content.alt: Diagram showing micro:bit ground pin connected with a crocodile clip lead to the tip of a headphone plug and micro:bit pin 0 connected to the long part of a headphone plug furthest from the tip

children.text: You can attach headphones or an amplified speaker to hear micro:bit
Connect pin 0 to the tip of a normal headphone plug, and connect the GND pin to the long part of the plug to complete the circuit. Sound will come out of just one side of the headphones.
The sound can be loud, so always test it out with headphones off before wearing them.
You can connect these pins using crocodile clips to metal foil to make your own switches or game controllers.
By default the pins work in
touch mode, which means you also need to touch the GND pin as well as pin 0, 1 or 2 to complete a circuit.
The pins on the micro:bit V2 can alternatively be made to work in
mode, which means you just need to touch the pin, but not GND as well.
This changes pin 1 to work with capacitive touch:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *


pin1.set_touch_mode(pin1.CAPACITIVE)

children.text: This changes it back to resistive touch:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *


pin1.set_touch_mode(pin1.RESISTIVE)

children.text: Pins 0, 1 and 2 can work as touch sensors when you also touch the GND pin to complete an electrical circuit:
To read the status of digital signals connected to pins 0, 1 or 2:
This will send a digital 1 (on) signal to pin 1:
You could connect a switch or button between the 3v pin and pin 1 and use this to test if the switch is open (0) or closed (1):
Never connect anything to the pins with a voltage over 3v or you may damage your micro:bit.

You can use pins 0, 1 and 2 in digital mode. This means they are either on (electricity is flowing through them, represented by the number 1) or off (no electricity is flowing through them, represented by the number 0).
Pins 0, 1 and 2 can work in analogue mode. This means instead of being off or on (0 or 1), they vary in value between 0 and 1023.
To read the status of analogue signals connected to pins 0, 1 or 2:

If you attach a wire to the 3V pin and another wire to pin 1 and touch the other ends of the wires across different materials, you can measure how relatively conductive they are. A reading of 1023 would be the most conductive and 0 the least conductive (effectively an insulator).
Never connect anything to the pins with a voltage over 3v.
This example varies the brightness of an LED connected to pin 1 and GND:

content.main:
from microbit import *


for i in range(1024):
    pin1.write_analog(i)
    sleep(3)

contents.name: Pins

children.text: NeoPixels are strips of LEDs that can be programmed individually to change colour and brightness. You can control them in your Python programs by importing the
Initialise NeoPixels with the correct pin and number of pixels (LEDs) for your hardware.
If you have a board with a micro:bit edge connector, the documentation for the accessory should tell you which pin the NeoPixel strip is connected to.
This will set up a strip of 8 NeoPixels controlled from micro:bit pin 0:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)

children.text: Note that you can set up and refer to your NeoPixels in your code by a different name.
could be any valid name such as one you’d use for a variable, so not a reserved Python keyword like
To change the colour of an individual NeoPixel, you need to know its position in the strip (starting at 0) and the colour you want as RGB (red, green, blue) values.
0 means a NeoPixel colour is off, 255 means it’s at its full brightness.
Note that the NeoPixels will not change colour or brightness until you use
This code will light the first NeoPixel (0) yellow (mixing red and green light) at 25% brightness (RGB 63, 63, 0):

content.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)
np[0] = (63, 63, 0)
np.show()

children.text: NeoPixels can be very bright, so it’s common to use numbers much smaller than 255. Also, NeoPixels powered by batteries will appear brighter when the batteries are fresh or fully-charged.
to light all the NeoPixels with the same colour and brightness.
This code lights all 8 NeoPixels blue at 25% brightness (RGB 0, 0, 63):

content.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)
np.fill((0,0,63))
np.show()

children.text: to light several NeoPixels using the same block of code.
This code will light 8 pixels one second after another, mixing red and blue to make the colour purple (RGB 127, 0, 127) at 50% brightness:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)
for pixel_id in range(len(np)):
    np[pixel_id] = (127, 0, 127)
    np.show()
    sleep(1000)

children.text: is the length of the NeoPixel strip set when it was initialised with
means you don’t have to remember the length of the NeoPixel strip when writing code, and means your code will also work with NeoPixel strips of different lengths.
This example repeatedly displays random colours on 8 NeoPixels controlled from pin 0:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel
from random import randint

# Setup the Neopixel strip on pin0 with a length of 8 pixels
np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)

while True:
    # Iterate over each LED in the strip
    for pixel_id in range(0, len(np)):
        red = randint(0, 60)
        green = randint(0, 60)
        blue = randint(0, 60)

        # Assign the current LED a random red, green and blue value between 0 and 60
        np[pixel_id] = (red, green, blue)

        # Display the current pixel data on the Neopixel strip
        np.show()
        sleep(100)

children.text: You can turn all the NeoPixels off using
This code lights the first 5 LEDs green at 25% brightness (RGB 0, 63, 0) and then switches them all off:

content.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)
for pixel_id in range(5):
    np[pixel_id] = (0, 63, 0)
    np.show()
    sleep(1000)

np.clear()

children.text: You can turn individual NeoPixels off by setting their RGB values to 0.
This code lights the first 5 NeoPixels, then switches off the middle one at position 2:

detailContent.main:
from microbit import *
import neopixel

np = neopixel.NeoPixel(pin0, 8)
for pixel_id in range(5):
    np[pixel_id] = (0, 63, 0)
    np.show()
    sleep(1000)

np[2] = (0, 0, 0)
np.show()

contents.subtitle: Use your computer’s keyboard & screen in micro:bit programs

children.text: If you’re using a Chrome or Edge web browser, you can access a serial console here in the editor. A serial console allows you to print information from your micro:bit on your computer screen, and use your computer’s keyboard to input information into your Python programs.

content.alt: Screen shot locating the 'show serial' button in the editor.

children.text: Plug your micro:bit into your computer’s USB socket, click on ‘connect’ then pair your micro:bit. When you flash a Python program to your micro:bit, you can access the serial console by clicking ‘Show serial’.

contents.name: Print output to the serial console

children.text: You can output text or numbers to the serial console using the

content.main:
from microbit import *


while True:
    print(display.read_light_level())
    sleep(1000)

children.text: This example prints the current light level once a second.
This can be really useful when debugging a program, or if you want to discover what ranges of sensor readings you get in a particular situation.
You can interact with Python micro:bit programs by entering text on your computer keyboard:

content.main:
name = input('What is your name? ')
print('Hello', name)

children.text: This example asks your name. When you click in the serial console, type your name and press enter, it will greet you.
You can use the serial console to type and execute Python commands directly on your micro:bit.

content.alt: Screenshot of the REPL being used in the serial console.

children.text: REPL stands for Read Evaluate Print Loop: the micro:bit reads your instruction, evaluates it, then prints the result in the serial console.
Having connected your micro:bit and flashed a Python program to it, break out of the program by pressing crtl+C to access the command prompt
to get some ideas about what you can do.

children.text: Bitwise operators allow you to perform operations on numbers at the bit, or binary, level.

output of any given digit will be 1 if both digits are 1. This example will mask out the the last (least significant) 4 bits and only keep the first (most significant) 4 bits of y. It will display 0b1010000.

content.main:
from microbit import *


x = 0b11110000
y = 0b10101010
display.scroll(bin(x & y))

children.text: will output a 1 if either digit is 1.

content.main:
from microbit import *


x = 0b11110000
y = 0b10101010
display.scroll(bin(x | y))

children.text: will output a 1 if either digit is 1

x = 0b11110000
y = 0b00011111
display.scroll(bin(x ^ y))

children.text: to shift binary digits left. Each shift to the left multiplies the number by 2. This shifts the number left by 4 digits. The result here is 0b11110000. Note that spaces are filled with zeroes.

to shift right. Each shift to the right divides the number by 2. This example shifts the digits 2 digits to the right. The result here is 0b11. Digits are lost as they move beyond the least significant digit.
performs a binary one’s complement operation on a number. In base 10 this has the effect of changing the number’s sign and subtracting one. This displays -0b1001 (-9 in denary / base 10):
